However this may be, Maternus is undoubtedly the protagonist of the picce. Itis through him that Tacitus gives expression to his own thoughts. The future historian saw that his work, too,

would be done, not in the bustle and rocket of the forum, but in quiet retirement. His regret for the old free-state was tempeted‚ like that of

Matemus‚ bya practical acquiescence in the necessity for the empire.

Itis his voice we seem to hear when the poet-pleader expresses his i

preference for Vergil’s life of repose (mato securum et quz'etum Vergilii secessum, 13. 4), and when, at the end of the debate, he points out that every age has its own advantages (nunc quombm nemo eodem tempore adsequi potest magnoni samam et magnam quatem, bono saeculi autquinque citra obtrectationem alterius utatur, ch. 41 ad fin). It is, in fact, by the closing speech that the so-called ‘republicanism’ of Maternus is reconciled and harmonized with existing political conditions.

Other theories of this closing speech have been put forward by editors, and remain to be considered. In this edition it is attributed to Matemus‚

not only on the evidence of the manuscripts, but on other grounds as , well. lt is in it that we find the fullest expression of that spiritual , sympathy between speaker and writer which was evidently Tacitus's ,

the true explanation of the placid manner in which, in the introduction, Maternus meets the hasty criticisms which are being advanced against his ‘Cato,' is to be found in his consciousness of his own position. In the first place, these criticisms are nothing but the outcome of popular gossip3 sabatae malignorum as they are styled even by the cautious Secundus¹ (3. 4). Aper does not seem to attach much weight to his friend's alleged indiscretion; to him it is simply an ‘outburst of his noble soul' (effervescit vis putcherrimae naturae tuoe), all the more dis· interested because it was connected with the name of one so far removed from present-day controversies (prabotas et nostri saemtt contoversrbs) as Cato.
